citation.article-title: Allisonella histaminiformans gen. nov., sp. nov. A novel bacterium that produces histamine, utilizes histidine as its sole energy source, and could play a role in bovine and equine laminitis.

p.s: Description of Allisonella histaminiformans sp. nov.
Allisonella histaminiformans (his.ta.min.i.for.mans N.L. neut n. histamini histamine; L. part adj. formans forming; N.L. part adj. histaminiformans histamine forming.)
Cells are ovoid shaped (0.4–0.8 × 1.0–8.0 μm long), are non-motile and occur in dipliod or chains.
Cells stain Gram-negative and are highly resistant to the ionophore, monensin.
Facultative anaerobic chemoheterotroph that utilizes histidine, producing histamine and CO2 as end-products.
Growth occurs in medium that contains yeast extract, butyrate and histidine.
The only other amino acid that is utilized is lysine, but lysine alone does not allow growth.
Carbohydrates and organic acids are not utilized.
Cellular yield is 1.5 mg protein per mmol of histidine.
Cells have a 110 min doubling time and grow optimally at 39 °C.
Volatile fatty acids are not produced and butyric acid is required for growth.
Cellular fatty acids profiles are dominated by C16 and C18 mono-unsaturated C16 fatty acids.
C16:0 saturated fatty acids account for less than 5% of the total.
The mol % guanine plus cytosine of DNA is 46.8 (thermal denaturation).

16S rRNA gene comparisons indicated that A. histaminiformans was most closely to Gram-positive bacteria, but these bacteria did not produce histamine. A. histaminiformans can be easily isolated from the rumen of cattle fed grain, but it could not be detected in cattle fed hay. A. histaminiformans can also be isolated at lower numbers from bovine feces and the cecum of a horse.
The type strain is MR2 (ATCC BAA610, DSM 15230).
